description: Rapid Action for Citizens with Earth Observation

links.title: Global temperature - ERA5
links.subtitle: Air temperature at 2m above
links.shortdescription: Surface air temperature data is crucial for assessing and forecasting health risks related to extreme heat (heatwaves) and cold. This information helps public health officials issue warnings, plan emergency responses, and study temperature-related illnesses such as heat stroke and cardiovascular issues.

links.title: Relative humidity - ERA5
links.subtitle: Global relative humidity
links.shortdescription: Relative humidity (RH), combined with temperature, determines how hot or cold air feels (the heat index).

links.title: Wind U Field
links.subtitle: Gridded ERA5 is the fifth generation ECMWF reanalysis for the global climate and weather for the past 4 to 7 decades. This parameter is the wind U field
links.shortdescription: The 10-meter (10m) u-component of wind velocity from the Copernicus Climate Data Store (CDS) is a fundamental meteorological variable used to calculate wind speed and direction near the Earth's surface. It represents the zonal wind flow (eastward wind, with positive values indicating flow from west to east) and, when combined with the v-component (northward wind), provides comprehensive data essential for numerous societal applications, particularly those impacted by wind power, severe weather, and ocean conditions.

links.title: Wind V Field
links.subtitle: Gridded ERA5 is the fifth generation ECMWF reanalysis for the global climate and weather for the past 4 to 7 decades. This parameter is the wind V field
links.shortdescription: The 10-meter (10m) v-component of wind velocity from the Copernicus Climate Data Store (CDS) is a fundamental meteorological variable representing the meridional wind flow (northward wind, with positive values indicating flow from south to north). When combined with the u-component (eastward wind), it allows for a complete calculation of wind speed and direction near the Earth's surface, which is critical for a wide array of societal applications.

links.title: Crop yield
links.subtitle: Yield forecast under "what-if" scenarios
links.shortdescription: Crop yield is typically a forecast or estimate of the quantity of an agricultural harvest. It is a critical metric that links climate, environment, and human activity, directly impacting global food security, the economy, and public welfare. The societal impacts of reliable crop yield indicators include Global Food Security, Market Stability and Economics, Climate Change Adaptation, Agricultural Policy and Planning, and Sustainable Resource Management. Indicators are often developed using a combination of ground based data and remote sensing data.
insituSources: Meteorological data from local Meteorological offices (AT)

links.title: Water demand
links.subtitle: Yield forecast under "what-if" scenarios
links.shortdescription: In agriculture, indocators of water need (often expressed as crop water requirements, irrigation demand, or evapotranspiration) provide essential data for optimizing water resource management, ensuring sustainable agriculture, and mitigating the impacts of droughts and climate change.
insituSources: Meteorological data from local Meteorological offices (AT)

links.title: Water turbidity
links.shortdescription: Water discharge — the volume of water flowing through a channel, such as a river or stream, per unit of time — is a fundamental metric for managing the global water cycle, ensuring public safety, supporting water resource management - including for drinking water and agriculture - and various economic sectors, and maintaining ecosystem health.
